description: A condition in which the blood pressure in the arteries is consistently elevated. It is often referred to as a 'silent killer' as it can lead to severe health problems like heart disease and stroke.
A group of diseases that affect how the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes are the most common forms.
A respiratory condition that causes narrowing and inflammation of the airways, leading to difficulty breathing, wheezing, and coughing.
A degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility.
A group of diseases involving abnormal cell growth with the potential to spread to other parts of the body. Types of cancer include breast cancer, lung cancer, and leukemia.
A long-term condition where the kidneys do not function as effectively as they should, leading to a buildup of waste and fluid in the body.
A progressive neurological disorder that causes brain cells to degenerate and die, leading to memory loss, confusion, and changes in behavior.
A contagious bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body. Symptoms include a persistent cough, weight loss, and fatigue.
An autoimmune disease that causes the body's immune system to attack the joints, leading to inflammation, pain, and potential joint deformity.
A viral infection that attacks the liver and can lead to both acute and chronic diseases. It is transmitted through contact with infected bodily fluids.
A neurological disorder characterized by recurring seizures caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
A genetic disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs and digestive system due to the production of thick, sticky mucus.
A disease where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing inflammation and damage to the nervous system.
A medical emergency that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, leading to brain damage and loss of function.

HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) attacks the immune system, and if left untreated, it can lead to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome), a condition where the immune system is severely weakened.
A condition where you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the body's tissues, leading to fatigue, weakness, and dizziness.
A neurodegenerative disorder that affects movement, causing tremors, stiffness, and difficulty with balance and coordination.
A viral infection that affects the liver, often leading to chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and liver cancer if left untreated.
A chronic autoimmune disease that leads to the rapid growth of skin cells, causing scaling, redness, and inflammation.
A blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle, resulting in damage or death of heart tissue.
A group of lung diseases that cause airflow blockage and breathing problems, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis.
